docs.lead_paragraph: Heavy drinking and smoking often go hand in hand. Now researchers are suggesting a possible reason. Nicotine appears to blunt the effects of alcohol, leading some people to drink more to achieve their desired level of intoxication, according to an article in the current Alcoholism: Clinical & Experimental Research.

docs.lead_paragraph: One thing a married couple might be expected to agree on would be whether to practice birth control. But in many cases, a new study finds, that is not so. An article in a recent issue of Studies in Family Planning reported significant discrepancies in the accounts by husbands and wives in 23 developing countries. The lead author, Prof. Stan Becker of Johns Hopkins University, said the findings were troubling for officials hoping to control population.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many hospital patients find it hard to figure out who their doctor is, given the bustle of doctors, residents, interns, nurses, technicians and assorted others in and out of their rooms. But a recent experiment at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., suggests an easy solution to that problem: mounting doctors' photographs on the walls of the patients' rooms.

headline.main: Hospitals Put Doctors in the Picture

docs.lead_paragraph: Children are more likely to be seriously injured on playground equipment than they are in bicycle or car crashes, researchers are reporting today. Writing in Ambulatory Pediatrics, researchers from the Children's Hospital Medical Center in Cincinnati said that more than 920,000 children ended up in emergency rooms in the United States during the six-year period they studied.

headline.main: Children Face Perils of the Playground

docs.lead_paragraph: Like many children of the 60's, David Kuhns dreamed of joining the Peace Corps right out of high school. And like most teenagers, he didn't have any skills to offer. So he studied to become a physician assistant, and in 1994 applied to go overseas with the aid group Doctors Without Borders. Founded in 1971, Doctors Without Borders sends some 2,000 volunteers to 80 countries each year, often directly to the world's most notorious war zones, including Beirut, Afghanistan and Sarajevo. Mr. Kuhns landed in Somalia during the country's civil war, not long after an American helicopter was shot down in Mogadishu, the capital, during a raid on a warlord's forces. The loss of 18 troops led to a recall of American forces.

docs.lead_paragraph: Taking estrogen after menopause does not necessarily prevent strokes or heart disease, according to the American Heart Association, which is changing its recommendations on the use of the hormone. Because it is not clear that the hormone has a preventive effect, and because of growing evidence that the supplements may cause harm in some patients, the association is now saying that preventing heart disease and strokes should not be the reason for prescribing hormone therapy.

headline.main: Heart Group Shifts Stance on Estrogen

docs.lead_paragraph: Don't worry so much about the cardiovascular workouts, the oat bran, the diet or the aspirin a day. They may all have benefits, but apparently they're minor compared with one simple thing to do to live longer, heal faster, lower blood pressure and cholesterol and have a better chance of surviving a heart attack. Get a pet.

headline.main: Pitter-Patter of Paws Is Time-Tested Remedy

docs.lead_paragraph: What are you doing now that you're retired? Or, if you are not yet retired, how are you planning to fill your days when you do? Playing golf? Watching television? Puttering around the house? Riding around in an R.V. spending your children's inheritance, to quote that popular bumper sticker? How long will such activities satisfy you? Will you feel as if you've been put out to pasture, no longer useful to anyone?

headline.main: Ways to Make Retirement Work for You

docs.lead_paragraph: Women who smoke may be reducing their chances of having a baby, a new study finds. Exposure to even a small amount of a class of chemicals in cigarette smoke may destroy a woman's eggs in the ovaries, researchers wrote in last week's issue of Nature Genetics.

headline.main: Smoking May Reduce Fertility in Women

docs.lead_paragraph: As the first recipient of a self-contained artificial heart enters his fourth week with the device, his surgeons say his recovery continues to exceed their expectations. The hopeful news raises a critical question: who will be the next to receive an AbioCor implant? In human experimentation, deciding who goes second can be as difficult as deciding who goes first. The AbioCor decision hinges on at least two crucial variables -- matching the readiness of a medical team with the availability of a suitable patient to volunteer. Unless both coincide there can be no experiment.

headline.main: The 2nd Artificial Heart: Patients Are Ready, but Not Surgeons
